subject: people are often cats
body:
comics from [ellen o'grady](https://www.instagram.com/ellenogradyart/?hl=en) about palestine (her most recent series: adaptations of letters she sent to her parents when she lived there: [1](https://www.instagram.com/p/C0MnctkL1FJ/?hl=en&img_index=3), [2](https://www.instagram.com/p/C0Zg2q0xwA6/?hl=en), [3](https://www.instagram.com/p/C0ZtpqDvFod/?hl=en)). the content is important but on the level of style i also love her framing and juxtaposition of different compositions, loose line work, and magical realist flourishes ([people are often cats](https://www.instagram.com/p/C0brQ9Asc4O/?hl=en&img_index=1)).

 ![image.png](/letters/images/574.webp) 

 ![image.png](/letters/images/573.webp) 

 ![image.png](/letters/images/575.webp) 

 ![image.png](/letters/images/572.webp) 

in other blessed comics news, [edith zimmerman is blogging again](https://kottke.org/) on kottke, including [diary comics](https://kottke.org/23/12/diary-comics-nov-1-2) (if you weren't aware, be sure to scroll back, she's been doing it for a week now). i also appreciated [her description of her process](https://kottke.org/23/11/my-writingdrawing-process) as i sit here both energized by the practice of regularly writing notes again but also resentful that it seems i have to keep doing it forever in order for my brain to not feel clogged up with thought all the time.
